title: Fig Farming in the North Central Region with Kris Heeter

tasks.task: Plant and care for cold hardy fig trees in ground and in pots.
subtasks: Source one-year-old cold hardy fig trees (Chicago hardy, Syrian dark, Abu George) from a local farm.
Prepare planting beds with compost, mulch, and protective barriers (cattle panels, living mulches) for in-ground trees.
Water trees weekly and manage deer protection using cattle panels and fencing.
Transfer potted trees to 10-gallon containers, mulch, and water weekly as needed.
Implement winter protection for in-ground trees by covering with mulch (leaves, wood chips, cardboard), and for potted trees, move indoors or cover with burlap/tar paper.

tasks.task: Experiment with fig varieties and growing conditions.
subtasks: Observe growth, disease, and pest pressure during the first year.
Adjust soil amendments and irrigation based on observed needs.
Train cordon-style trees using aluminum pipes and bamboo supports to promote horizontal growth.

tasks.task: Explore value-added products from fig trees.
subtasks: Gather unripe figs for jam-making experiments.
Harvest fig leaves for tea blends and evaluate market interest.
Document potential post-harvest uses (e.g., latex sap collection, jam and preserves) for farmer education.
Participate in grant-funded outreach and demonstrations (e.g., farm field days, educational seminars) to share results and promote fig farming.

tasks.task: Conduct soil and compost analysis for improved tree health.
subtasks: Test soil fertility and adjust organic matter levels based on analysis.
Apply compost and mulch to enhance soil structure and nutrient retention.
Monitor tree growth and nutrient uptake based on soil testing results.

tasks.task: Plant and care for cold-hardy fig trees in ground and in pots.
subtasks: Source one-year-old cold-hardy fig trees (Chicago hardy, Syrian dark, Abu George) from a local farm.
Prepare planting beds with compost, mulch, and protective barriers (cattle panels, living mulches) for in-ground trees.
Water weekly and manage deer protection using physical barriers.
Train cordon-style trees using horizontal pipes and bamboo supports.
Cover in-ground trees with protective mulch (leaves, wood chips, cardboard) for winter.

tasks.task: Plant and care for cold-hardy fig trees in pots.
subtasks: Source one-year-old cold-hardy fig trees (Chicago hardy, Syrian dark, Abu George) from a local farm.
Pot trees in 10-gallon containers with mulch for moisture retention.
Water weekly and monitor soil moisture.
Protect potted trees by moving them indoors or covering with protective materials like burlap or tar paper in winter.

tasks.task: Experiment with value-added products from fig trees.
subtasks: Test unripe figs for jam-making and preserve production.
Collect and process fig leaves for herbal teas.
Market and distribute value-added products to local markets and through farmer networks.

tasks.task: Participate in a USDA SARE grant project.
subtasks: Collaborate with other farmers and research partners as part of a grant project.
Attend educational events and provide feedback on grant-supported activities.
Participate in outreach efforts to educate other farmers on successful fig farming techniques.

tasks.task: Conduct soil and mulch analysis for improved tree growth.
subtasks: Conduct soil tests to determine nutrient needs and adjust organic matter levels.
Apply appropriate mulch and compost to enhance soil structure and moisture retention.
Monitor tree growth and adjust soil management practices based on observations.
